txt: My brigade has more than 50 active members
My brigade has become preoccupied with requiring projects to be politically correct. Not just do good government.
I want my brigade to serve as a partner & champion for traditionally marginalized groups who are otherwise underserved by local government.
My brigade needs funding or assistance with fundraising to reach our full potential
Code schools / bootcamps are a great recruiting source for brigade volunteers. We don't teach code, but we introduce students to civic tech.
Members of my brigade would appreciate being matched to projects that fit their interests and skills, even if they weren't local
Brigades' focus should be on improving tech. delivery in government, and are not well positioned to try to be everything to everyone.
My brigade doesn't do enough to center the voices of those our technology most impacts.
My brigade struggles to maintain more than 6 active members at a time.
I want my brigade to develop technology that expands the impact of local social justice groups.
I believe brigades must engage more actively in advocacy to have long-term change on the problems we seek to address
Not formally, but how we do everything: learning through doing.
My Brigade wants to have a sustainable funding model.
My brigade trains future public servants with digital delivery skills.
I want my brigade to be seen as a go-to resource for digital expertise among local government staff.
I attended my first brigade meeting over 2 years ago.
I'd like my brigade to find a better way to use the adjacent policy expertise we often attract but can't retain.
My brigade provides digital services and capacity to local government starved for these resources.
My brigade spends too much time reinventing the wheel instead of iterating and innovating.
My brigade prioritizes amiable government partnerships over community needs.
Our community needs a brigade because our city IT department uses every excuse to gatekeep and build power for themselves over the people.
I want my brigade to practice age equity in its recruitment to achieve diversity of experience in its project teams.
My brigade funnels new and emerging technologists into “good tech”
Brigades are not a place for folks to learn to code, but for those with skills to give back.
My brigade doesn’t value the time or effort of its members and will discard work that is done by them.
Our brigade serves as a matchmaker, connecting stakeholders from different sectors and fields who may have shared interests.
Our nearby city comes to our brigade with internal (but open souce) projects that need a new stakeholder to reach their potential.
My Brigade wants to run regular events in more areas of our city
My brigade wants to lift up the science and technology of indigenous people
I want my brigade to serve as a partner and champion of government partners.
Our brigade has been most successful when we've partnered with local nonprofits and social workers.
My brigade has more positive impact by helping participants better understand government and civics, than by building tech tools.
My brigade trains locaal government and non-profit partners
My brigade is majority technologists with little to no civics understanding.
I believe brigades can overcome social inequality and economic inequality utilizing various resources at their disposal.
My brigade has fewer than 10 active members
A technologist's role in community problems is to democratize access to technology
My brigade changes the conversation locally through long-term government partnerships
My brigade has said they want to share their work/learnings, since every insight & every code snippet has the power to make us all better.
Maintaining high-quality software projects long-term without the support of paid staff is not realistic for my brigade.
I want my brigade to use tech to elevate & amplify the intrinsic knowledge of our local marginalized & underrepresented communities.
CfA should partner with existing open source projects for good, like Mozilla Fdn, Wikimedia, etc
Our volunteers are DE-motivated by periods of inaction more than anything else.
My brigade provides volunteers that resource projects from other brigades
The nonprofit community has a much better understanding of the needs of individuals and families seeking help from government resources.
I want my brigade to organize with others in our community so that technology (Facial recognition) isn't used to discriminate in our city.
My brigade receives enough support from Code for America.
I want my brigade to push back on local government when we see systemic inefficiencies and inequities in service delivery.
My brigade offers workforce development for my local community
The "principles and practices of the digital age" have different meaning at local vs national government, nonprofits, and tech companies
My brigade solves local problems with the tools of technology, locally.
My brigade advises local government and non-profit partners
I want my brigade to deliver quickly enough on important projects so our community partners succeed, appreciate us, and brag on us.
I want my brigade to deliver end-to-end technology solutions to local government, similar to how a vendor might.
My brigade creates new civic technologists.
My brigade gives a voice to people impacted by government services
I believe brigades are most effective when working in partnership with local, community based organizations.
More than anything else, our volunteers are motivated by personal, tangible contributions to meaningful work.
Occasionally; also we work with several different local cities due to the nature of the geography of local munis.
My brigade provides volunteers that resource projects from other local initiatives
A year from now, our brigade is likely to have more active local members.
My brigade is getting better at working with people-powered community partners.
My brigade has the capacity to pursue multiple projects.
My brigade members have said they just want to work on a specific project.
Principles, yes; products, not generally.
My brigade leadership does not enjoy doing fundraising work.
I want my brigade to partner with and learn from local government when we see systemic inefficiencies and inequities in service delivery
My brigade provides digital services and capacity to local nonprofits starved for these resources.
My brigade cannot align our work with CfA's projects because we don't know what CfA is doing or how we can collaborate.
My brigade wants volunteers from local private technology companies.
Our local government is focused on internnal performance KPIs and not projects in the public interest.
My brigade needs help recruiting members.
More than anything else, our volunteers are motivated by highly-impactful projects.
More than anything else, our volunteers are motivated by being part of a like-minded community.
My brigade trains others (technologists, gov staff, nonprofits, activists) on how to apply the principles and practices of the digital age.
Technologists aren't always the best people to solve community problems.
I want to be part of a National Brigade that fixes systemic federal government problems. (Even if fed gov is not asking for help).
The “principles & practices of the digital age” embed inequity and bias into our technology. I want brigades to work toward changing this.
I want my brigade to develop tech solutions that are scalable across our local government partners.
My brigade leadership does not enjoy doing organizing work.
My brigade struggles to complete projects.
My brigade, OpenOakland, has become a slave to require projects to be politically correct.  Not just do good governement.
This is a substantial focus of our work.
I want my brigade to augment or expand our local government’s digital capacity.
We should be spending more time working with and educating elected officials.
My brigade does projects as experiments that push government to view its own mandate in those areas differently.
Money is one of the top issues preventing progress in my brigade.
My brigade volunteers serve as the thought leaders and practitioners of the civic technology ecosystem.
My brigade scales Code for America products and principles.
My brigade advocates for good technical policy and against bad policy.
My brigade wants local private tech companies to sponsor us.
I want my brigade to be seen as a go-to resource for digital expertise among local community groups.
My brigade is struggling to deliver value to partners *and* to enable volunteers to engage productively.
I want my brigade to leverage data to build understanding and trust between our community and our government.
My brigade holds my local government accountable
I believe, if we work together, we can find thoughtful ways to advance diversity/equity/inclusion without sacrificing transparency.
My brigade leadership is overwhelmed by the amount of work to be done.
I want my brigade to be better at storytelling.
I want my brigade to raise the visibility of issues of equitable service delivery in our community.
